text: Poem: Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif. In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Introduction. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon our master Muhammad and upon his brothers among the Prophets and Messengers, and upon his family, companions, and the followers. To proceed: This is a gentle explanation on the poem of Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad bin Sayyid Al-Jakani Al-Shinqiti in the science of Morphology called 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif'. In it, I limited myself to resolving its wording and clarifying its intent in a gentle manner free from stuffing and verbosity. I named it 'Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif'. I ask Allah to benefit through it, and He is sufficient for me and the best Disposer of affairs.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: I praise my Lord, Who has disposed the universe... ........................................ The Explanation. The author said, seeking blessings by the Great Name of Allah and following His Generous Book: (In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful), meaning: I compose [poetry]; for every doer who begins his action with 'In the name of Allah' implies what made the Basmalah a beginning for it. Just as a traveler, if he settles or departs and says: 'In the name of Allah', the meaning is 'In the name of Allah I settle', and 'In the name of Allah I depart'. (Allah) is a proper name for the Necessary Existent Essence. (Al-Rahman, Al-Rahim) are two names built for exaggeration from 'Rahima' (to have mercy), and Al-Rahman is more emphatic than Al-Rahim; because the increase in structure indicates an increase in meaning. (I praise my Lord) 'Hamd' (Praise) linguistically is: praising with the tongue for optional beauty by way of glorification. 'Al-Rabb' (The Lord) is one of the names of Allah Almighty. (Who has disposed the universe) meaning: The One who managed this universe, for He is the One disposing in it by creation and annihilation. In the author's phrase: (Who has disposed the universe) there is what is called 'excellence of the opening' (Bara'at al-Istihlal). Its meaning according to rhetoricians is that the speaker mentions in the beginning of his speech something that alludes to his intent. Here, the author presented this phrase at the beginning of his poem to subtly indicate what he will talk about in it, which is the science of Morphology (Tasrif).

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ................. ... He sent blessings and peace upon the one He honored. The Explanation. (He sent blessings) It is famous that 'Salah' (blessings/prayer) from Allah Almighty means mercy, from angels it means seeking forgiveness, and from humans it means supplication and prayer. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar chose in 'Fath Al-Bari' that the meaning of Allah's Salah upon His Prophet is His praising him and honoring him, and the Salah of angels and others upon him is requesting that for him from Allah Almighty. (And peace) from 'Taslim', meaning peace/safety. Some said: Establishing Salah and Salam after the Basmalah in the opening of books and letters originated during the rule of Banu Hashim, then the practice continued as recommended. Some scholars also conclude books with them (1). (Upon the one He honored) meaning: Upon the one whose status and rank He raised. 'Sharaf' (Honor) is highness and elevation. (Alladh) is a dialectal form of 'Alladhi' (The one who).

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Muhammad and his family, and to proceed... ....................................... The Explanation. (Muhammad) is an appositive (Badal) for (the one He honored). Muhammad is a proper name for our Prophet, peace be upon him. His grandfather Abd al-Muttalib named him so by inspiration from Allah Almighty that creation would praise him much due to his many praiseworthy qualities, as narrated in biographies. (And his family) are, according to the most correct view, the believers of Banu Hashim and Banu Al-Muttalib. (And to proceed) meaning: And after what preceded of praise and prayers and peace. This phrase, whether it follows 'Amma' or not, is brought to transition from one style to another. It is not permissible to bring it at the very beginning of speech. It is recommended to bring it in sermons and correspondence, following the example of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Al-Bukhari dedicated a chapter to it in his Sahih. There is disagreement regarding the first person to say it, with eight opinions summarized by someone in two verses: Dispute occurred regarding who first started with "Amma ba'du" ... Opinions were counted, and Dawood is closest. And Ya'qub, Ayyub the Patient, Adam ... And Quss, Sahban, Ka'b, and Ya'rub.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ....................... ... So take from verb conjugation a necklace. For it is an art of majestic worth ... And ignorance of it is truly shameful for a person. The Explanation. (So take) 'Hak': A verbal noun imperative meaning 'Take'. (From verb conjugation a necklace) He likened his poem to a necklace strung with gems, beads, and the like that is hung around the neck. He specified conjugation to the verb in his saying (from verb conjugation) because he did not speak in this poem except about the conjugation of the verb specifically. Originality in conjugation belongs to verbs; due to their frequent changes, and it only entered nouns by analogy to verbs. (For it) meaning: The science of Morphology. (Is an art of majestic worth) meaning: Of great status. It is among the most glorious Arabic sciences and greatest in importance; because it deals with the core of Arabic words, and acts as a standard and scale for them. (And ignorance of it is truly shameful for a person) meaning: That a student of knowledge's ignorance of the science of Morphology attaches a defect to him and decreases his rank.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: I mentioned in it what is needed ... And from the Lord is assistance. I named it 'The First Fruits of Introduction' ... To what concerns us of Morphology. The Explanation. (I mentioned in it what is needed) meaning: He mentioned regarding verb conjugation what is indispensable. (And from the Lord is assistance) meaning: Assistance is sought from Allah Glory be to Him, not from others. Bringing forward the object in his saying: (And from the Lord is) indicates exclusivity (Hasr). (I named it 'The First Fruits of Introduction') meaning: He named this poem of his (Bakurat Al-Ta'rif). 'Bakurah' of a thing is its first fruit/beginning. So it is the first introduction to the science of Morphology; because he mentioned in it the most important rules indispensable for a student of this art. (To what concerns us of Morphology) meaning: To the most important aspects of the science of Morphology; because knowledge is vast and life is short, so the student of knowledge prioritizes the most important, then the important. Thus Ibn al-Wardi said: And life falls short of acquiring every science ... So begin from it with the most important.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: .................................. The Explanation. Structure (Mabna), Weight (Wazn), Form (Sigha), and Shape (Hay'a) are synonymous terms. It is said: The structure of the word - meaning: its weight. By 'structure' is meant the shape of the word in which others can share. This shape consists of the number of letters in the word, their order, their movements (vowels) and stillness (sukoon), taking into account extra and original letters. So "Rajul" (man) - for example - is on a shape and form that can be shared by the word "Adud" (upper arm) and similar words that consist of three letters, the first of which is open (Fatha) and the second is joined (Damma). Thus, the science of Morphology investigates the conditions of word structures that are not inflection (I'rab) or construction (Bina', indeclinability). The science of Syntax (Nahw) investigates the endings of words in terms of inflection and construction. Its subject matter: Arabic words in terms of investigating their soundness and infirmity (Ilal), their originality and addition, and so on. It is specific to declinable nouns (Mu'rab) and conjugatable verbs (Mutasarrif). Particles (Harf) of all kinds, indeclinable nouns (Mabni), and rigid verbs (Jamid) are not investigated in the science of Morphology.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ................................ The Explanation. 'Tasrif' (Morphology) linguistically: Absolute change. From it is 'Tasrif al-riyah' (the changing of winds), meaning their changing and turning. Terminologically: A science in which the conditions of Arabic word structures are investigated, and what pertains to their letters of originality and addition, soundness and infirmity, and so on. 'Abniyah' (structures) is the plural of 'Bina' (structure), 'Binyah', and 'Bunyah'. Its founder: Mu'adh bin Muslim Al-Harra (1). Its fruit: Preserving the tongue from error in Arabic vocabulary, leading to understanding the language which leads to understanding the Book of Allah Almighty. By knowing it, forms, their diminutives, and attributions are regulated. Its source: From the Book (Quran), the Sunnah, and the speech of the Arabs. Its ruling: A communal obligation (Fard Kifaya). Its issues: Its propositions mentioned therein, like our saying: 'Daraba' is a bare verb (Mujarrad), 'Akrama' is an augmented verb (Mazid), and 'Fa'ula' with a Damma on the 'Ayn' has its present tense as 'Yaf'ulu', and so on.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Chapter on the Structures of the Bare Verb (Mujarrad). The Explanation. (Chapter on the Structures of the Bare Verb) 'Abniyah' (structures) as mentioned before is the plural of 'Bina' (structure). Intended by structures of the bare verb are the forms upon which the bare verb comes. Before mentioning these weights for the bare verb, we clarify that the verb is divided into bare (Mujarrad) and augmented (Mazid): The verb bare of addition is: The verb whose letters are all original. An original letter is: The letter that sticks to the word in all its conjugations. The augmented verb is: That which has one or more extra letters. An extra letter is: The letter that drops in some conjugations of the word, like the Alif in "Qatala, Daraba", the Ta and Alif in "Taqatala, Taghafala", and the Hamza, Sin, and Ta in "Istaghfara, Istaqama".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: The weight of the bare verb according to them is Fa'ala ... Fa'ila along with Fa'ula then Fa'lala. The Explanation. Addition is either a repetition of an original letter or not. If it is a repetition of an original, it is not restricted to the letters of addition. If it is not a repetition of an original, it can only be one of the ten letters gathered in your saying: "Sa'altumuniha". These letters are called letters of addition. The meaning of naming them letters of addition is that no letter is added for other than repetition except from them. The meaning is not that these letters never occur as original in speech; for they may occur as original like "Mata, Sa'ala". He said: (The weight of the bare verb... etc. the verse). The author mentioned in this verse the weights of the bare verb, which are four weights: three for the trilateral (three-letter) past tense, and one for the quadrilateral (four-letter) past tense. As for the weights of the trilateral: 1 - "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn', like: Daraba (hit), Nasara (helped), Dakhala (entered), Kharaja (exited), Akala (ate). 2 - "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn', like: Marida (became sick), Fariha (rejoiced), 'Ajila (hurried), Ghalita (erred), Fashila (failed). 3 - "Fa'ula" with Damma on the 'Ayn', like: 'Azuma (became great), Karuma (became noble), Kabura (became big), Saghura (became small).

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Kataba along with 'Alima then Zarufa ... Dahraja ........................... The Explanation. As for the weight of the quadrilateral, it is: "Fa'lala" with Sukoon on the 'Ayn' and Fatha on the rest, like: Ba'thara (scattered), Hashraja (rattled in throat), Hadhrama (spoke fast), Bartama (1), 'Arbada (2). Then the author proceeded in the following verse to give examples for the four weights mentioned above, saying: (Kataba along with 'Alima then Zarufa Dahraja). His saying: "Kataba" (wrote) is an example for the first weight "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn'. His saying: "'Alima" (knew) is an example for the second weight "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn'. His saying: "Zarufa" (was witty/elegant) is an example for the third weight "Fa'ula" with Damma on the 'Ayn'. His saying: "Dahraja" (rolled) is an example for the quadrilateral weight "Fa'lala".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ........................... ... ......... representation by folding that fulfilled. The Explanation. Then he said: (Representation by folding [Laff] that fulfilled [Wafa]). 'Laff wa Nashr' (Folding and Unfolding/Involution and Evolution) is one of the semantic embellishments. It is: Mentioning multiple things in detail or generally, then mentioning what belongs to each without specification (1) relying on the intelligent listener to attribute each to its counterpart. If the speaker brings multiple items, and after that brings another set of multiple items where each individual relates to an individual of the former in detail and without assignment, this act is called "Laff wa Nashr". If it is in order, such that the first is for the first and the second for the second and so on, then the Laff wa Nashr is ordered (Murattab). Otherwise, it is disordered (Ghayr Murattab). Here, the folding happened in order. The author gave examples for the four weights mentioned in the previous verse according to their order of mention. He started by exemplifying Fa'ala with "Kataba", then exemplified Fa'ila with "'Alima", then exemplified Fa'ula with "Zarufa", then exemplified Fa'lala with "Dahraja". And his saying: (Qad Wafa) - It is said: Wafa al-shay' yafi, meaning: It was complete/fulfilled.
foot_note: 1. If he specifies, it is called Division (Taqsim), not Laff wa Nashr.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Chapter on Conjugation of the Present Tense. Fa'ula with Damma adheres to intransitivity ... ...................................... The Explanation. Chapter on Conjugation of the Present Tense. When the author finished discussing the weights of the bare verb, he proceeded to discuss the present tense of each of the four preceding weights, saying: (Fa'ula with Damma adheres to intransitivity) meaning: "Fa'ula" with Damma on the 'Ayn' adheres to being intransitive (Luzum), so its verb only comes as intransitive. An intransitive verb (Lazim) is: One that is satisfied with its subject (Fa'il), meaning: it suffices with it and has no object, like: Zaid stood (Qama Zaid), Amr sat (Qa'ada Amr), Bakr went out (Kharaja Bakr). Or it has an object but does not reach it except through a preposition, like: I passed by Zaid (Marartu bi-Zaid). A transitive verb (Muta'addi) is: One that reaches the direct object without a preposition, like: I hit Zaid (Darabtu Zaidan), I honored Amr (Akramtu Amran).

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ..................... ... And Damma of what is present tense from it is known. And open for it from the one with Kasra in the past ... ...................................... The Explanation. Its sign: That a pronoun 'Ha' can be attached to it which does not refer to the verbal noun (Masdar), like: "The door, I closed it" (Al-Babu Aghlaqtuhu). The pronoun - the Ha - is a direct object referring to the door, which is not a verbal noun. So "Fa'ula" with Damma on the 'Ayn' is never anything but intransitive, like: "Karuma (was noble), Shaju'a (was brave), Hasuna (was beautiful), Qabuha (was ugly), Qasura (was short), Fazu'a (was horrible)". He said: (And Damma of what is present tense from it is known) meaning: Every verb on the weight of "Fa'ula" always has its present tense on the weight of "Yaf'ulu" with Damma on the 'Ayn', like: "Karuma Yakrumu, Hasuna Yahsunu, Qabuha Yaqbuhu, Qasura Yaqsuru, 'Azuma Ya'zumu, Sharufa Yashrufu" and so on. He said: (And open for it) meaning: for the present tense (from the one with Kasra in the past) meaning: from "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn'. Every verb on the weight of "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn', its present tense comes on the weight of "Yaf'alu" with Fatha on the 'Ayn', like: "Fariha Yafrahu, Hazina Yahzanu, 'Atisha Ya'tashu, Shariba Yashrabu, Shabi'a Yashba'u, 'Alima Ya'lamu, Radiya Yarda, Sakira Yaskaru, Ghadiba Yaghdabu" and so on.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ......................... ... It dominates in colors and defects/accidents. And break it in "Warith" "Warim" "Wali" "Wathiq" ... "Wariya Mukhkhun" and "Wari'" "Wafiq" "Wamiq" The Explanation. And his saying: (It dominates in colors and defects/accidents) meaning: The form "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn' predominantly indicates colors and accidents (A'rad). Accidents are attributes that do not permanently stick to the essence, but come and go like illness and joy. An example of what indicates colors: Hamira (became red), Sawida (became black), Khadira (became green), Safira (became yellow). And an example of what indicates accidents: Fariha (rejoiced), Hazina (grieved), Marida (became sick), Barisa (became leprous), Jariba (became scabby), Nashita (became active), Shabi'a (became full), 'Atisha (became thirsty), Ta'iba (became tired). He said: (And break it in "Warith" "Warim" ... etc. the verse). It was mentioned in the previous verse that the present tense of "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn' originally comes with Fatha like "Yafrahu". There are verbs on the weight of "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn' for which only the anomalous Kasra was heard in their present tense. Their number is thirteen. The author mentioned eight of them, which are: "Waritha Yarithu (inherited), Warima al-jurhu Yarimu (the wound swelled), Waliya Yali (governed/followed), Wathiqa Yathiqu (trusted), Wariya

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Two faces from it in "Hasib" "Na'im" "Ba'is" ... "Waghir" "Wahir" "Walih" "Wahil" "Yabis" "Ya'is". The Explanation. al-Mukhkhu Yari (the marrow became abundant), Wari'a al-rajulu Yari'u (the man was pious/abstained), Wafiqa al-farasu Yafiqu (the horse was excellent/suitable), Wamiqa Yamiqu (loved)". These eight verbs did not appear in the Arabic language except with Kasra in the present tense, even though the rule for their present tense is Fatha. The meaning of Warima is: swelled. Wariya al-Mukhkh is: increased. Wari'a is: left doubtful matters fearing falling into the forbidden. Wafiqa al-Faras is: became good. Wafiqta amraka is: you found it suitable. Wamiqa is: loved. He said: (Two faces from it in "Hasib" "Na'im" ... etc. the verse). After the author mentioned what was heard with only Kasra in the present tense of "Fa'ila", he proceeded to discuss the verbs in which two faces were heard: the measured Fatha and the anomalous Kasra. They are twelve verbs. The author mentioned nine of them in this verse, which are: Hasiba Yahsabu and Yahsibu, Na'ima Yan'amu and Yan'imu, Ba'isa Yab'asu and Yab'isu, Waghira Yaugharu and Yaghiru, Wahira Yauharu and Yahiru, Waliha Yaulahu and Yalih, Wahila Yauhalu and Yahilu, Yabisa Yaybasu and Yaybisu, Ya'isa Yay'asu and Yay'isu". The meaning of Hasiba is: thought. Na'ima al-rajulu is: his condition became good. Ba'isa if his condition became bad. Waghira sadruhu is: burned with rage. Wahira is: filled with grudge. Waliha, so he is Walih and Walhan, if he almost lost his mind due to losing a beloved one from family or wealth. Wahila 'an al-shay' is: forgot it. Yabisa al-shajaru is: its moisture went away. Ya'isa is: if his hope was cut off. When he finished discussing the present tense of "Fa'ula" with Damma on the 'Ayn', and "Fa'ila" with Kasra on the 'Ayn', he moved to discuss the present tense of "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn'.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: The coming of Fa'ala the Open is broken in ... A Waw-Fa or intransitive doubled Or Ya-i (1) in its Ayn or its Lam ... ........................................ The Explanation. He said: (The coming of Fa'ala is broken) meaning: its present tense; because the present tense is called "Al-Ati" (The Coming). (The Open) meaning: open 'Ayn' (vowel a). (In a Waw-Fa or intransitive doubled or Ya-i in its Ayn or its Lam) meaning: "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn' has the 'Ayn' of its present tense broken (Kasra), so it is said: "Yaf'ilu" if a cause (2) from the four causes of Kasra mentioned in the poem is found, which are: 1 - That the Fa of "Fa'ala" is a Waw (3). To this the author pointed by saying: (In a Waw-Fa). Examples of this are: "Wa'ada Ya'idu (promised), Wajada Yajidu (found), Wasafa Yasifu (described), Wasala Yasilu (arrived), Wa'aza Ya'izu (preached)" (4). They stipulate that its Lam should not be a guttural letter (5). If it is so, the 'Ayn' of its present tense is opened (Fatha), like: "Waqa'a Yaqa'u (fell), Wada'a Yada'u (left), Wada'a Yada'u (placed)".
foot_note:
1. Thus it appeared in the poem "Aw Ya'iyan" (accusative), and the correct way is to say "Aw Ya'iyin" (genitive) because it is conjoined to a genitive noun. However, for what the author mentioned there is a justification, which is that his saying: "Ya'iyan" is the predicate (Khabar) of "Kana" whose name is deleted, so the estimation is: "Aw Kana al-fi'lu ya'iyan" (Or if the verb was Ya-i). However, what we mentioned was better because what has no estimation is prioritized over what has estimation. 
2. 'Jawalib': Plural of 'Jalib'. A 'Jalib' according to morphologists is the cause/inviter. It is said: Jalib al-kasr, meaning: the cause for Kasra. 
3. Scholars of Morphology chose a standard and morphological scale against which they compare the roots of words that they encounter. They composed the scale from three letters; because most words in the Arabic language are trilateral. They made these three letters: "Fa'ala", which are the Fa, the 'Ayn', and the Lam. They named the first letter corresponding to Fa: Fa of the word. The second letter corresponding to 'Ayn': 'Ayn of the word. The third letter corresponding to Lam: Lam of the word. So the Kaf of "Kataba" - for example - is the Fa of the word, the Ta is the 'Ayn' of the word, and the Ba is the Lam of the word, and so on. They adhere to the form of the scale with the same movements and stillness of the weighed word, so they say: "Kataba" is on the weight of "Fa'ala", "Fahima" is on the weight of "Fa'ila", "Karuma" is on the weight of "Fa'ula", and so forth. 
4. The Waw was deleted in all these verbs because it occurred between the open Ya (Fatha) and the Kasra. The origin is "Yaw'idu... etc". The rule is that if Waw falls between them, it is deleted. Ibn Malik said: The Fa of an imperative or present tense from like "Wa'ada" delete, and in like "'Idah" this is consistent. 
5. The guttural letters are six: Hamza, Ha, 'Ayn, Ha (unemphatic), Ghayn, and Kha.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Explanation. 2 - That "Fa'ala" is doubled (1) intransitive. To this the author pointed by saying: (Or intransitive doubled). Examples of this are: "Dabba Yadibbu (crawled), Farra Yafirru (fled), Khaffa Yakhiffu (lightened), Dalla Yadillu (strayed), Hanna Yahinnu (yearned), Qalla al-shay'u Yaqillu (the thing became little), Tanna Yatinnu (buzzed), Anna Ya'innu (groaned), Ranna Yarinnu (rang)". 3 - That "Fa'ala" is Ya-i in the 'Ayn' (middle radical is Ya), like: "Ja'a Yaji'u (came), Qa'a Yaqi'u (vomited), Ghaba Yaghibu (was absent), Qala Yaqilu Qaylulatan (napped), Khaba Yakhibu (failed), Zada Yazidu (increased), 'Asha Ya'ishu (lived), Mala Yamilu (leaned)". 4 - That "Fa'ala" is Ya-i in the Lam (last radical is Ya), like: "Ata Ya'ti (came), Baka Yabki (cried), Bana Yabni (built), Rama Yarmi (threw), Zana Yazni (committed adultery), Hadha Yahdhi (deliriously spoke), 'Asa Ya'si (disobeyed), Jara Yajri (ran)". However, it is stipulated that its 'Ayn' should not be a guttural letter. If it is a guttural letter, the 'Ayn' of the present tense is opened (Fatha), like: "Ra'a Yara (saw), Ra'a Yar'a (grazed/tended), Sa'a Yas'a (strove), Naha Yanha (forbade)". The author pointed to the third and fourth causes of Kasra by saying: (Or Ya-i in its Ayn or its Lam).
foot_note: 1. Intended by 'doubled' here is the trilateral doubled: which is what had its 'Ayn' and 'Lam' of the same kind, like: "Shadda, Madda, Hanna". Their origin is: "Shadada, Madada, Hanana".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ....................... ... Its two Waws, there is no doubt in its joining (Damma). Likewise what came for overcoming in pride, or ... Doubled if it is transitive ................. The Explanation. Then when he finished with the causes of breaking (Kasra) the present tense of "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn', he proceeded to discuss the causes of joining (Damma) the present tense, which are also four, saying: (Its two Waws, there is no doubt in its joining, likewise what came for overcoming in pride, or doubled if it is transitive). Meaning: That "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn', the 'Ayn' of its present tense is joined (Damma) so it is said: "Yaf'ulu", if a cause - motive - from the four causes of Damma mentioned in the poem is found. These are: 1 - That the 'Ayn' of "Fa'ala" is a Waw, like: "Qala Yaqulu (said), Dhaba Yadhubu (melted), Fata Yafutu (passed), Na'a Yanu'u (rose heavily), Jada Yajudu (was generous), Faza Yafuzu (won), Khada Yakhudu (waded), Ja'a Yaju'u (hungered), Tafa Yatufu (circumambulated)" (1). 2 - That the Lam of "Fa'ala" is a Waw, like: "Da'a Yad'u (called), Bada Yabdu (appeared), Zaka Yazku (grew/purified), Rashahu Yarshuhu (bribed him), Saba Yasbu (yearned), 'Afa Ya'fu (forgave), 'Ada Ya'du (ran/transgressed), Ghaza Yaghzu (raided), Fasha Yafshu (spread), Haja Yahju (satirized), Hafa Yahfu (slipped)" (2). To this cause and the one before it, the author pointed by saying: (Its two Waws, there is no doubt in its joining), meaning: That "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn', if it has a Waw 'Ayn' or Lam, there is no doubt - meaning: no uncertainty - in joining (Damma) the 'Ayn' of its present tense.
foot_note:
1. In all examples mentioned like "Qala, Dhaba, Jada", the Alif is changed from Waw. 
2. In all examples mentioned like "Da'a, Bada, Zaka, Saba, Fasha, Haja", the Alif is changed from Waw.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: .................. The Explanation. 3 - That "Fa'ala" indicates overcoming in boasting (Mughalaba), like: "Sara'ani fa-sara'tuhu fa-ana asru'uhu" (He wrestled me and I defeated him, so I defeat him), "Tadarabna fa-darabtuhu fa-ana adrubuhu" (We hit each other and I hit him [better], so I hit him [better]), "Tanasarna fa-nasartuhu fa-ana ansuruhu" (We helped each other and I helped him [better], so I help him [better])". Every verb intended to indicate that two people boasted in a matter and one overcame the other in it, its present tense has a joined 'Ayn' (Damma). This is what is meant by the author's saying: (Likewise what came for overcoming in pride). His saying: (Li-badhdhi al-fakhr) means: for overcoming in boasting. "Al-Badhdh" here is not a dialectal variant of "Al-Badhl" (giving) as might be imagined. 4 - That "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn' is doubled and transitive, like: "Sabba Yasubbu (insulted), Madda Yamuddu (extended), Sabba Yasubbu (poured), Fatta Yafuttu (crumbled), Hajja al-bayta Yahujjuhu (performed Hajj to the House), Radda Yaruddu (returned/replied), Hattha Yahuththu (urged), Baththa al-khabara Yabuththuhu (spread the news), Darrahu Yadurruhu (harmed him), Rashsha Yarushshu (sprinkled), Dakka Yadukku (pounded), Zaffa al-'arusa Yazuffuha (led the bride)". To this cause the author pointed by saying: (Or doubled if it is transitive), meaning: That one of the causes for Damma in the present tense of "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn' is that it comes as doubled and transitive.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: 5 - .......................... ... ............................. And they narrated by hearing the Kasra, and in Habba it was alone ... ....................................... The Explanation. He said: (And they narrated by hearing the Kasra, and in Habba it was alone). It was mentioned previously that the standard rule for "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn' which is doubled and transitive is that its present tense comes with Damma on the 'Ayn'. However, some verbs deviated from this. The deviation is of two types: 1 - What was heard with the standard Damma and the anomalous Kasra. These are nine verbs, including: "Shaddahu Yashudduhu and Yashidduhu (pulled it), Namma al-haditha Yanummuhu and Yanimmuhu (spread the talk maliciously), Shajjahu Yashujjuhu and Yashijjuhu (broke his head), Battahu Yabuttuhu and Yabittuhu (cut/decided it)". This is what is meant by the author's saying: (And they narrated) meaning: in the present tense of the transitive doubled Fa'ala (by hearing the Kasra) meaning: along with Damma, and that is in the nine verbs. 2 - What was heard with only the anomalous Kasra and nothing else. This is in one verb, which is: "Habba", its present tense is "Yahibbu" with Kasra on the Ha (1). This is what is meant by the author's saying: (And in Habba it was alone) meaning: Kasra was solitary, and Damma was not heard in it according to the rule.
foot_note: 1. As for "Yuhibbu" with Damma on the present tense letter - the Ya - it is the present tense of the quadrilateral "Ahabba", not the trilateral "Habba".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ............................ ... And Damma of intransitive by hearing has occurred. The Explanation. He said: (And Damma of intransitive by hearing has occurred). It was mentioned previously that the standard rule is Kasra on the 'Ayn' of the present tense of Fa'ala - with Fatha on the 'Ayn' - if it is intransitive like "Farra Yafirru". However, some verbs deviated from this where Damma of their present tense was heard. This deviation is of two types: 1 - What was heard with the standard Kasra and the anomalous Damma. These are many verbs, including: "Sadda Yasiddu and Yasuddu (turned away/repelled) (1), Kharra al-hajaru Yakhirru and Yakhurru (the stone fell), Haddati al-mar'atu Tahiddu and Tahuddu (the woman mourned), Shadhdha Yashidhdhu and Yashudhdhu (was odd/deviated), Shahha Yashihhu and Yashuhhu (was miserly)". 2 - What was heard with only the anomalous Damma. These are also many verbs, including: "Habbati al-rihu Tahubbu (the wind blew), Hamma bi al-amri Yahummu (intended the matter), Marra Yamurru (passed), Shakka - meaning: doubted - Yashukku, Janna al-zalamu Yajunnu (darkness covered), Rashsha Yarushshu (sprinkled), Tashsha Yatushshu (drizzled), Thajja Yathujju (flowed copiously)".
foot_note: 1. With both ways - Kasra and Damma - the verse was recited: {And when the son of Mary was presented as an example, immediately your people laugh aloud [Yasidduna]} Az-Zukhruf: 57.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: And the Fatha in a guttural 'Ayn' is mandatory ... Or Lam ............................ The Explanation. When the author finished discussing the causes of Kasra and Damma, he proceeded to discuss the causes of Fatha, saying: (And the Fatha in a guttural 'Ayn' is mandatory, Or Lam). He mentioned that it is mandatory to open (Fatha) the 'Ayn' of the present tense of "Fa'ala" if a cause from the causes of Fatha is found in it. These are two: 1 - That the 'Ayn' of "Fa'ala" is one of the guttural letters. Hence the author said: (And the Fatha in a guttural 'Ayn' is mandatory) meaning: It is mandatory to open the 'Ayn' of the present tense of "Fa'ala" if the 'Ayn' is guttural. His saying: (The Fatha) is the subject (Mubtada), and (mandatory) is its predicate (Khabar). Examples of this are: "Sa'ala Yas'alu (asked), Bahatha Yabhathu (searched), Ba'atha Yab'athu (sent), Bahata Yabhatu (astounded), Lahatha Yalhathu (panted), Nahara Yanharu (slaughtered), Shaghara al-makanu Yashgharu (the place became vacant), Nahasha Yanhashu (bit)". 2 - That the Lam of "Fa'ala" is one of the guttural letters. Hence the author said: (Or Lam) meaning: It is mandatory to open the 'Ayn' of the present tense of "Fa'ala" if it has a guttural Lam, just as it is mandatory if it has a guttural 'Ayn'. Like: "Khasha'a Yakhsha'u (humbled), Khada'a Yakhda'u (submitted), Bada'a Yabda'u (began), Hada'a Yahda'u (calmed), Sharaha Yashrahu (explained), Raka'a Yarka'u (bowed), Khala'a Yakhla'u (took off), Rafa'a Yarfa'u (raised), Zara'a Yazra'u (planted), Raqa'a Yarqa'u (patched), Nasaha Yansahu (advised), Shara'a fi al-amri Yashra'u (started the matter), La'ana Yal'anu (cursed), Fataha Yaftahu (opened)".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ....................... ... ......... If the cause is absent in it. The Explanation. However, it is stipulated for the opening (Fatha) of the present tense of "Fa'ala" that there should be no cause for Kasra or Damma. Hence the author said: (If the cause is absent in it) meaning: the cause for Kasra and Damma. But if a cause for Kasra or Damma is found, it prevails and is prioritized over the cause for Fatha, except for what was previously excepted; because the cause for Fatha is the weakest of causes. Like: "Da'a". It is said: Da'ahu - meaning: pushed him violently - Yadu'uhu - with Damma on the 'Ayn' (1), even though its 'Ayn' and 'Lam' are guttural. Its 'Ayn' is the letter 'Ayn', and its 'Lam' is also 'Ayn'; because its origin is "Da'a'a". Yet, the cause for Damma, which is "Fa'ala" being doubled and transitive, was prioritized. Another example is: "Bagha" (sought/transgressed). It is said in its present tense: "Yabghi" with Kasra, even though a cause for Fatha was found in it, which is the 'Ayn' of the word being a guttural letter. However, it was opposed by a cause for Kasra, which is the Lam being Ya-i (a Ya), so the cause for Kasra was prioritized over the cause for Fatha.
foot_note: 1. From it is His saying Almighty: {The Day they are thrust toward the fire of Hell with a [violent] thrust} At-Tur: 13.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: With fame ........................ ... ....................................... The Explanation. Then he said: (With fame) meaning: It is also stipulated for the opening (Fatha) of the present tense of "Fa'ala" that there is no fame (Shuhrah). If the verb became famous among the Arabs with Kasra or Damma, then fame is prioritized and prevails over the cause for Fatha; because fame is stronger than the cause. Examples of this are: "Qa'ada (sat), Za'ama (claimed), Akhadha (took), Dakhala (entered), Sa'ala (coughed), Nakhala (sifted)". For these examples, the rule suggests opening the 'Ayn' of their present tense; because their 'Ayn' is a guttural letter. However, Damma became famous in their present tense, so it is said: "Yaqu'udu, Yaz'umu, Ya'khudhu, Yadkhulu, Yas'ulu, Yankhulu". Examples also include: "Nafakha (blew), Sarakha (screamed), Balagha al-sabiyyu (the boy reached puberty), Tala'at al-shamsu (the sun rose)". For these examples, the rule suggests opening the 'Ayn' of their present tense; because their Lam is a guttural letter. However, Damma became famous in their present tense, so it is said: "Yanfukhu, Yasrukhu, Yablughu, Tatlu'u". Another example is: "Shakhara - meaning: made a sound from his throat and nose -". The rule suggests opening the 'Ayn' of its present tense; because its 'Ayn' is a guttural letter. However, Kasra became famous in its present tense, so it is said: "Yashkhiru". Other examples are: "Raja'a (returned), Naza'a (removed)". The rule suggests opening the 'Ayn' of their present tense; because their Lam is a guttural letter. However, Kasra became famous in their present tense, so it is said: "Yarji'u, Yanzi'u".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: And what deviated from all ... So break or join (Damma) from it a coming [present tense] like 'Atala. The Explanation. He said: (And what deviated from all, So break or join from it a coming [present tense] like 'Atala). Meaning: Whatever is free from all the previous causes, so no cause for Kasra, Damma, or Fatha is found in it, and is free from fame so it was not famous among the Arabs for anything specific; then it is permissible for the 'Ayn' of its present tense to have Kasra or Damma. Like: 'Atala. Hence the author said: (Like 'Atala) - and 'Atl is: Pushing with violence and force - so you say in its present tense: Ya'tilu and Ya'tulu" (1). And his saying: (Atin) meaning: present tense; because the present tense is called "Al-Ati" as we presented.
foot_note: 1. With both ways - Kasra and Damma - the verse was recited: {Then drag him to the center of the Hellfire} Ad-Dukhan: 47.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Explanation. Summary: The trilateral bare verb has six chapters (Abwab) regarding its present tense: First Chapter: Fa'ula Yaf'ulu - with Damma on the 'Ayn' in both past and present -, like: Karuma Yakrumu. Second Chapter: Fa'ila Yaf'alu - with Kasra on the 'Ayn' in past, and Fatha in present -, like: Fariha Yafrahu. Third Chapter: Fa'ila Yaf'ilu - with Kasra on the 'Ayn' in both past and present -, like: Waritha Yarithu. Fourth Chapter: Fa'ala Yaf'ilu - with Fatha on the 'Ayn' in past, and Kasra in present -, like: Daraba Yadribu. Fifth Chapter: Fa'ala Yaf'ulu - with Fatha on the 'Ayn' in past, and Damma in present -, like: Nasara Yansuru. Sixth Chapter: Fa'ala Yaf'alu - with Fatha on the 'Ayn' in both past and present -, like: Fataha Yaftahu.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: And the summary of what relates to "Fa'ala" with Fatha on the 'Ayn' is as follows: 1 - The 'Ayn' of its present tense is broken (Kasra) if it has a Waw Fa, or is intransitive doubled, or has a Ya 'Ayn' or Lam. 2 - The 'Ayn' of its present tense is joined (Damma) if it has a Waw 'Ayn', or Waw Lam, or indicates overcoming, or is transitive doubled. 3 - The 'Ayn' of its present tense is opened (Fatha) if it has a guttural 'Ayn' or guttural Lam, and is free from causes of Kasra and Damma, and free from fame among Arabs [for other vowels]. 4 - If it is free from causes of Kasra, Damma, and Fatha, and was not famous among Arabs for anything, then Kasra and Damma are permissible in the 'Ayn' of its present tense.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Then when the author finished discussing the weight of the trilateral present tense, he moved to discuss the weight of the quadrilateral present tense, saying: The present of the quadrilateral is broken just as ... What exceeded three, and generalize. The Explanation. (The present of the quadrilateral is broken) meaning: That every bare quadrilateral verb like "Dahraja", its present tense comes with Kasra on the letter before the last, like: "Yudahriju, Yuzalzilu, Yuhashriju, Yubartimu, Yu'arbidu". His saying: (broken) meaning: what is before its end. His saying: (just as what exceeded three) meaning: just as the letter before the last is broken in the present tense of the augmented trilateral, like: Yantaliqu - present of the five-letter verb Intalaqa -, Yastakhriju - present of the six-letter verb Istakhraja. His saying: (and generalize) meaning: Generalize this ruling, which is breaking the letter before the last of the augmented present tense. However, this generalization is questionable; because the trilateral verb beginning with an extra Ta has the letter before its last opened (Fatha) in the present tense as will come, like: "Yataghafalu, Yataqatalu, Yatakallamu, Yata'allamu, Yataqaddamu, Yatakallafu". The Alif in his saying (Wa 'ammima) is changed from the lightened energetic Nun when stopping; because the original is to say: (Wa 'ammiman) but he deviated from that to observe the meter.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Alert Your distinguishing the Ya from the Waw is by an 'Ayn' ... ........................................ The Explanation. Alert. 'Tanbih' (Alert) linguistically: Awakening. Terminologically it is: Following previous speech by mentioning a partial matter included in it implicitly. If we wish, we can say in defining it: It is speech detailing what was summarized before it (1). It would have been better for the author to say: "Mas'alah" (Issue) instead of saying: "Tanbih"; because this issue which the author spoke about in this alert was not mentioned previously at all. In these verses, the author wanted to clarify the method by which the Alif is known whether it is changed from Waw or from Ya. He said: (Your distinguishing the Ya from the Waw is by an 'Ayn') meaning: If you want to distinguish the 'Ayn' of the verb

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ............................ ... By connecting the moving nominative [pronoun], it becomes clear. The Explanation. whether it is changed from Waw or Ya like "Qala, Ba'a, Tala, Khafa, Haba", then bring the moving nominative pronoun like the Ta of the speaker, and connect it to the verb whose 'Ayn' you want to distinguish (1). Hence the author said: (By connecting the moving nominative, it becomes clear) meaning: That if you connect to the end of the verb one of the moving nominative pronouns (2), the 'Ayn' of the verb will appear, and it will become clear whether it is Waw or Ya. His saying: (By an 'Ayn') meaning: Located in the 'Ayn' of the word. His saying: (Yabin) meaning: Appears.
foot_note:
1. Benefit: Ibn Hisham said: "If the matter of a verb confuses you, connect it with the Ta of the speaker or addressee, whatever appears is its origin. Do you not see that you say in Rama and Hada: Ramaytu and Hadaytu, and in Da'a and 'Afa: Da'awtu and 'Afawtu. If the matter of a noun confuses you, look at its dual form, whatever appears in it is its origin. Do you not see that you say in Al-Fata and Al-Huda: Al-Fatayan and Al-Hudayan, and in Al-'Asa: Al-'Asawan. How beautiful is the saying of Al-Shatibi [i.e., in Hirz Al-Amani] may Allah have mercy on him: And dualizing nouns reveals them and if ... you return the verb to yourself you find a source. Al-Hariri, may Allah have mercy on him, said: If a verb one day its spelling obscures you ... then attach the Ta of address to it and do not stop. If you see it with Ya one day write it ... with Ya, otherwise it is written with Alif. ... See: Sharh Qatr Al-Nada (p. 331 - 332). 
2. The moving nominative pronouns are: The Ta of the doer like "Darabtu", the Nun of females like "Khifna", and the Na of doers like "Qulna".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: And transferring the vowel/shape of its 'Ayn' to the Fa ... If the past of this was joined (Damma) or broken (Kasra). The Explanation. Then he said: (And transferring the vowel/shape of its 'Ayn' to the Fa, If the past of this was joined or broken). 'Shakl' (Shape): Vowel. The meaning is that the past verb whose 'Ayn' is joined (Damma) or broken (Kasra), if you connect it with a moving nominative pronoun, you transfer the vowel of the verb's 'Ayn' to the Fa. Example of what has a broken 'Ayn': "Khafa" (feared), its origin is "Khawifa". The vowel letter moved and the letter before it was opened, so it had to be changed to Alif, so it is said: "Khafa". If you connect it with a moving nominative pronoun like the Ta, you say: "Khiftu". The origin is "Khawiftu". The vowel of the Waw was transferred to the Kha after removing its vowel, then the Waw was deleted due to the meeting of two sukoons - the Waw and the Fa - so it became "Khiftu" on the weight of "Filtu". The remaining of the Kasra on the Fa of the word is evidence that its 'Ayn' is Ya. His saying: (Dha'i) is a demonstrative noun for the singular masculine.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: But with the open [Ayn], the homogeneous ... Is transferred, not the vowel/shape, according to what they established. The Explanation. Then the author said: (But with the open [Ayn], the homogeneous is transferred, not the vowel/shape, according to what they established). Meaning: That if the 'Ayn' of the past verb is open (Fatha) and we connect it to a moving nominative pronoun, what is transferred is the vowel homogeneous to the 'Ayn', not its own vowel; because its vowel is Fatha, and there is no benefit in transferring Fatha to Fatha. Rather, we give the Fa a vowel homogeneous to the letter of the 'Ayn'. If the letter of the 'Ayn' is Waw, we give the Fa Damma; because it is homogeneous to Waw. And if the letter of the 'Ayn' is Ya, we give the Fa Kasra; because it is homogeneous to Ya. Example of what has Waw as 'Ayn': "Qala" (said), its origin is "Qawala". The vowel letter moved and the letter before it was opened, so it had to be changed to Alif, so it is said: "Qala". If we connect a moving nominative pronoun to it, it becomes "Qultu". The presence of Damma on the Fa is evidence that the Alif is changed from Waw. And example of what has Ya as 'Ayn': "Ba'a" (sold), its origin is "Baya'a". The vowel letter moved and the letter before it was opened, so it had to be changed to Alif, so it is said: "Ba'a". If we connect a moving nominative pronoun to it, it becomes "Bi'tu". The presence of Kasra on the Fa is evidence that the Alif is changed from Ya. The author's saying: (the homogeneous is transferred) contains some leniency; because there is no transfer here in reality, unlike what preceded regarding the joined and broken. His saying: (according to what they established) meaning: according to what they founded and set rules for.

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: Chapter on the Present Tense. And with "Na'aytu" the present tense is started ... And open ................................. The Explanation. Chapter on the Present Tense. The author mentioned in this chapter the letters with which the present tense begins, the vowel of these letters, and the vowel of the letter before the last. He started with what starts the present tense, saying: (And with "Na'aytu" the present tense is started). Meaning: That the present tense verb must begin with one of the four letters collected in your saying: "Na'aytu" (1), like: "Najlisu, Ajlisu, Yajlisu, Tajlisu". These four letters are called the letters of the present tense (Mudaara'ah). Then the author proceeded to discuss the vowel of these letters, saying: (And open) meaning: Open these letters if the verb is trilateral like "Yadribu, Tansuru, Aftahu", or five-lettered like "Yantaliqu, Najtami'u, Ata'allamu", or six-lettered like "Yastakhriju, Nastaghfiru".
foot_note: 1. They are also collected in the word "Anaytu" and "Na'ti".

book_title: Fath Al-Karim Al-Latif fi Sharh 'Bakurat Al-Ta'rif bil-Muhimm min Al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmad Al-Shinqiti
text: ............................. ... ............... And in the quadrilateral, Damma occurs. And what is before the last, open if it started ... With Ta ................................... The Explanation. He said: (And in the quadrilateral, Damma occurs) meaning: As for the present tense of the quadrilateral, the letter of the present tense in it is joined (Damma) according to all Arabs. So you say: "Yudahriju, Nukrimu, Tukhbiru, Usafiru, U'allimu" and so on. Then when he finished discussing the vowel of the present tense letter with which the present tense verb opens, he proceeded to discuss the vowel of the letter before the last, saying: (And what is before the last, open if it started with Ta) meaning: That the augmented past verb starting with an extra Ta that is customarily added (1) - and it is only five-lettered like "Takallama, Taqaddama, Ta'allama, Taqatala, Taghafala" - has the letter before the last of its present tense opened. So you say: "Yatakallamu, Yataqaddamu, Yata'allamu, Yataqatalu, Yataghafalu" and so on.
foot_note: 1. Our saying: "customarily added" is to exclude the Ta of "Tarmasa al-shay'" - meaning: hid it in the Rams (grave) - for its addition is not customary, but was brought to enable pronunciation of the quiescent letter, which should start with Hamza not Ta. That is why some use it as a riddle saying: What is the letter that is not a Hamza of connection used to enable pronunciation of a quiescent letter?

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
.......................... … ...... And others have passed [first of all / from the beginning] 

The Explanation: He said: (And others have passed, badi badi) meaning: Speech regarding that which does not begin with 'Ta' has already passed, and that was in the chapter on the conjugation of the Present Tense (Mudari'). For that which does not begin with 'Ta' is either triliteral like "daraba" (hit), "fataha" (opened); or quadriliteral like "dahraja" (rolled), "ba'thara" (scattered); or pentaliteral like "intalaqa" (set off), "inkasara" (broke), "ijtama'a" (gathered); or hexaliteral like "istaghfara" (sought forgiveness). If it is quadriliteral, pentaliteral, or hexaliteral, it is obligatory to break (Kasra) the letter before the last in the Present Tense, such as: "yudahriju", "yuba'thiru", "yukrimu", "yuslimu", "yusafiru", "yu'allimu", "yuqaddimu", "yantaliqu", "yankasiru", "yajtami'u", "yastaghfiru" and so on. If it is triliteral like "fataha", "daraba", "nasara", "karuma", speech regarding it has already preceded in detail, and we explained that the letter before the last in its Present Tense might be open (Fatha) like "yaftahu", "yafrahu", "yas'alu", "yakhsha'u", "yakhda'u", "yakhla'u". It may be broken (Kasra) like "ya'ti", "yabki", "yabni", "yarmi", "yahdhi", "ya'si", "yajri", "yamshi", "yazni". And it may be joined (Damma) like "yad'u", "yabdu", "yazku", "ya'fu", "ya'du", "yaghzu", "yafshu", "yahju", "yahfu". And his saying: (badi badi) means: at the beginning of the matter. Ibn al-Athir said: "Al-Badiyy with stress (shadda): The first, and from it is their saying: Do this 'badiya badiyin'. Meaning: First of all things" (1). Al-Radi said while discussing this phrase: "Its usage became so frequent that the combination of the two words conveyed what is conveyed by a single word, as the meaning of 'badi badi' is: starting" (2).
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Nihayah fi Gharib al-Athar (1/271). 
2. See: Sharh al-Radi 'ala al-Kafiyah (3/139).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
Chapter on what is built for the Unknown (Passive Voice)

And the verb, if built for the object (Passive) … Join (Damma) its beginning ...................................

The Explanation: Chapter on what is built for the Unknown (Passive Voice). He said: (And the verb, if built for the object, join its beginning) meaning: That the verb—whether triliteral or exceeding three letters—if you wish to build it for the object (meaning: for that whose doer is not named), you apply Damma to its beginning, whether it is Past or Present tense. His saying: (Dumm) is an imperative verb, and the doer is a hidden pronoun estimated as (you). An example of the Triliteral Past: "duriba" (was hit), "futiha" (was opened), "suriqa" (was stolen), "hufiza" (was preserved), "fuhima" (was understood), "kutiba" (was written), "ukhidha" (was taken), "ukila" (was eaten), "qutila" (was killed). An example of the Present Triliteral verb: "yudrabu", "yuftahu", "yusraqu", "yuhfazu", "yufhamu", "yuktabu", "yu'khadhu", "yu'kalu", "yuqtalu". An example of the Past exceeding three letters: "duhrija", "tu'ullima", "tusuddiqa", "untuliqa", "ujtumi'a", "ustukhrija". An example of the Present exceeding three letters: "yudahraju", "yuba'tharu", "yuntalaqu", "yujtama'u", "yustakhraju".

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
........................ … ....... And break the weak [verb] like 'shim' 

The Explanation: He said: (And break the weak (1) like 'shim') meaning: If the Past Triliteral verb has a weak middle letter (Hollow verb) like: "qala" (said), "ba'a" (sold), "ja'a" (came), "kada" (almost did), and it is constructed for the object (Passive), then its beginning is broken (Kasra), so it is said: "qila", "bi'a", "ji'a" (2). And his saying: (like 'shim'), 'shim' is an imperative verb from 'shama al-barq'. And 'al-shaym' is: looking at the lightning, watching where it intends to go and where it will rain. It is said: 'shama al-barqa yashimuhu shayman'" (3).
foot_note:
1. The verb is divided into two types: Sound (Sahih) and Weak (Mu'tall). The Sound is: what is free of the three vowel letters - Alif, Waw, and Ya. The Weak is: what has one of its original letters as a vowel letter. It is divided into five types: First: Mithal: What has a weak first letter (Fa), like: wa'ada, warima. Second: Ajwaf (Hollow): What has a weak middle letter ('Ain), like: ba'a, qala, khafa, qama, sama. Third: Naqis (Defective): What has a weak last letter (Lam), like: rama, baka, bagha, radiya, da'a. Fourth: Lafif Maqrun: What has a weak middle and last letter, like: tawa, rawa, hawa, nawa, lawa, shawa. Fifth: Lafif Mafruq: What has a weak first and last letter, like: wafa, waqa, wa'a, waliya. 
2. What the poet mentioned regarding breaking the first letter of the hollow verb when built for the passive is the most eloquent, although pure Damma is permissible - which is the dialect of Faq'as and Dubayr - so you say: "bu'a", "qula", "suma". From this is the poet's saying: "Layta wa hal yanfa'u shay'an laytu .... layta shababan bu'a fa-ashtaraytu" (If only youth were sold so I could buy it). Ishmam is also permissible, which is: mixing the sound of Damma with a bit of the sound of Kasra. 
3. Al-Qamus al-Muhit (p. 1456), Islah al-Mantiq by Ibn al-Sikkit (p. 16).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And what is before the last of the Past is broken … And opening it in the Present is transmitted.
In "ikhtara" and "inqada" and the like, break … the first and the third, and be precise.

The Explanation: He said: (And what is before the last of the Past is broken) meaning: If the Past verb is built for the object (Passive), the letter before its last is broken (Kasra), such as: "kusira", "duriba", "futiha", "suriqa", "hufiza", "fuhima", "kutiba", "ukhidha", "ukila", "qutila". He said: (And opening it in the Present is transmitted) meaning: And the letter before its last is opened (Fatha) if it is Present tense, such as: "yuksaru", "yudrabu", "yuftahu", "yuhfazu", "yufhamu", "yuktabu", "yu'kalu", "yuqtalu". And his saying: (uthira) means: transmitted from the Arabs. He said: (In "ikhtara" and "inqada" and the like, break the first and the third, and be precise) meaning: In "ikhtara" (chose) and "inqada" (obeyed/led), the first and third letters are broken, so you say: "ikhtira" (was chosen) and "inqida" (was led). 

And what begins with Hamzat al-Wasl, then join … its third like the second of the one with 'Ta', it is obligated.

And his saying: (and the like) means: Whatever resembles them from every verb on the weight of "ifta'ala" or "infa'ala", which has a weak middle letter and a sound last letter; its ruling is like their ruling, meaning its first and third letters are broken (1). And his saying: (wa harriri) is from Tahrir, which is refinement. Perhaps the poet intended to clarify by this phrase that what does not meet the aforementioned conditions of being on the weight of "ifta'ala" or "infa'ala", such as "istawa" (2), is not given their ruling. Rather, it is like others starting with Hamzat al-Wasl, having only the joining (Damma) of its first and third, as will come in the next verse, which is his saying: And what begins with Hamzat al-Wasl, then join … its third like the second of the one with 'Ta', it is obligated.
foot_note:
1. Pure Damma is also permissible, so you say: "ukhtura", "unquda", and Ishmam (mixing vowels) is also permissible. 
2. And similar verbs where a condition from the aforementioned conditions is missing, which here is the soundness of the last letter, for its last letter is weak.

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And what begins with Hamzat al-Wasl, then join … its third like the second of the one with 'Ta', it is obligated.

The Explanation: (And what begins with Hamzat al-Wasl, then join its third like the second of the one with 'Ta', it is obligated) meaning: The Past verb starting with Hamzat al-Wasl - which is only pentaliteral or hexaliteral - if built for the object (Passive), it is obligatory to join (Damma) the third letter of it - meaning: along with the first -, such as: "untuliqa", "ujtumi'u", "ustukhrija", "ustughfira", "ustunbita". It would have been better to present this verse before the verse preceding it; because what was mentioned in the previous verse is an exception to this rule. So it was better to present the mention of the rule, then mention what is excepted from it, which is every verb on the weight of "ifta'ala" or "infa'ala" with a weak middle and sound last. And his saying: (like the second of the one with 'Ta') meaning: The verb starting with an extra 'Ta' has its second letter joined - meaning: along with the first - like "ta'allama", "tasaddaqa", "taqatala", so you say in their passive forms: "tu'ullima", "tusuddiqa", "tuqutila".

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
Chapter on the Imperative (Amr)
And the Imperative from 'af'ala' is 'af'il' ............ … ........................................

The Explanation: Chapter on the Imperative. The poet spoke in this chapter about how to form the imperative verb. The summary of this chapter is that the Past verb is either on the weight of "af'ala" or not. If it is on the weight of "af'ala" with a Fatha on the 'Ain', then the imperative from it comes on the weight of "af'il" with a Kasra on the 'Ain'. This is the meaning of the poet's saying: (And the Imperative from 'af'ala' is 'af'il'). Examples of this are: "akrim" (honor), "ahsin" (do good), "a'ti" (give), "amin" (believe). For the past tense of these commands are: "akrama", "ahsana", "a'ta", "amana". So the difference between the Past form and the Imperative - as you see in the examples - is that the letter before the last is open in the Past, and broken in the Imperative (1).
foot_note: 1. Another difference between them is that the last letter in the Past is open (Fatha), and in the Imperative, it is silent (Sukun), although the vowel of the last letter is not a topic of Morphology (Sarf), but rather a topic of Syntax/Grammar (I'rab).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
................. And delete … from other than it the Mudari' letter, you will suffice.

The Explanation: And if the Past is not on the weight of "af'ala", such as being triliteral like "daraba", or quadriliteral not on the weight of af'ala like "dahraja", or pentaliteral like "intalaqa", or hexaliteral like "istakhraja", then the method of deriving the imperative verb from it is to bring the Present verb (Mudari') in the Jussive case (Majzum) with the Lam of Command (Lam al-Amr). Then the Lam of Command and the Mudari' letter (prefix) are removed from it. Then one looks at the letter that was connected to the Mudari' letter; if it has a vowel, then you obtain the imperative verb directly, such as: "li-tudahrij", "li-tuzakhrif", "li-tusaddiq", "li-tusharik", "li-tuqatil", "li-tataqaddam", "li-taqul", "li-tasum". You say in the imperative from them: "dahrij", "zakhrif", "saddiq", "sharik", "qatil", "taqaddam", "qul", "sum". This is what is meant by the poet's saying: (And delete from other than it the Mudari' letter, you will suffice) meaning: Remove the Mudari' letter from other than "af'ala" and you will fulfill what is required of you. But if the letter connected to the Mudari' letter is silent (Sukun), then a Hamzat al-Wasl is brought to enable the pronunciation of that silent letter. This Hamza is broken (Kasra) if the Mudari' has a broken middle letter like "yadribu", or an open middle letter like "yadhhabu", "ya'lamu", so you say in the imperative from them: "idrib", "idhhab", "i'lam".

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And the silent one, join it with a broken Hamza … if the coming [verb] is opened, likewise if broken.
And join it from what is joined originally ........ … ..............................................

The Explanation: The poet pointed to this by saying: (And the silent one, join it with a broken Hamza if the coming is opened, likewise if broken) meaning: If the letter following the Mudari' letter is silent, join it with a broken Hamzat al-Wasl if the Mudari' is open or broken. His saying: (if the coming is opened) refers to the Mudari'. He said: (And join it from what is joined originally) meaning: And apply Damma to the Hamzat al-Wasl if the middle letter of the Present verb is joined with an original Damma. Examples of this: "yansuru", "yaqtulu", "yanzuru", "yaktubu", "yad'u". These are Present verbs with a joined middle letter, so you say in the imperative from them: "unsur", "uqtul", "unzur", "uktub", "ud'u". And his saying: (from what is joined originally) is a precaution against cases where the Damma of the Mudari's middle letter is temporary (accidental). In that case, the Hamzat al-Wasl is brought broken, because the temporary is weak and does not override the original. So you say: "imshu" (walk - plural) with a broken Hamzat al-Wasl, even though the middle letter of the Present verb assigned to the Waw of the group is joined "yamshun", but this Damma is temporary because of the Waw of the group.

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
...................... And anomalous is … the deletion of it from 'kul' and 'mur' and 'sal' and 'khudh'

The Explanation: And his saying: (And anomalous is the deletion of it from 'kul' and 'mur' and 'sal' and 'khudh') meaning: The deletion of Hamzat al-Wasl is anomalous (irregular) in limited verbs, which are: "kul" (eat), "mur" (order), "sal" (ask), "khudh" (take), even though the principle is to keep it; because the letter connected to the Mudari' letter is silent, and the analogy in such cases is to establish the Hamzat al-Wasl. So the original forms would be: "u'kul", "u'mur", "is'al", "u'khudh". However, since the Arabs deleted this silent letter connected to the Mudari' letter, they dispensed with bringing the Hamzat al-Wasl; because it was imported to enable pronunciation of the silent letter, and that has been removed, so they deleted it, and they became "kul", "mur", "sal", "khudh". However, the deletion of the Hamza in "mur" and "sal" is not obligatory except when starting speech with the word. But if preceded by a conjunction, they are not committed to deleting it; rather, the most common usage for these two words in that case is restoring the Hamza, like His saying (Exalted is He): {Wa'mur ahlaka bi-as-salah} (And enjoin prayer upon your family), {Fa-as'alu ahla al-dhikr} (So ask the people of the message). As for "khudh" and "kul", completing them after a conjunction is rare.

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
Chapter on the Active Participle (Ism Fa'il) and Passive Participle (Ism Maf'ul)
'Fa'ula' with Damma, 'Fa'il' [or] 'Fa'l' … is the Active Participle for it, like "Zaydun Sahlun"
And 'Fa'il' for 'Fa'ila' with Kasra, perpetuate … like 'Af'al', 'Fa'lan' if it was intransitive.

The Explanation: Chapter on the Active Participle and Passive Participle. The poet said: ('Fa'ula' with Damma, 'Fa'il' [or] 'Fa'l' is the Active Participle for it, like "Zaydun Sahlun") meaning: Every verb on the weight of "fa'ula" - its Active Participle by analogy comes on the weight of "fa'il" or on the weight of "fa'l". Whatever deviates from these two weights is anomalous, preserved but not used for analogy. Examples of what came on the weight of "fa'il": "karuma fa-huwa karim" (generous), "nabula fa-huwa nabil" (noble), "qabuha fa-huwa qabih" (ugly), "qasura fa-huwa qasir" (short), "'azuma fa-huwa 'azim" (great), "sharufa fa-huwa sharif" (honorable), "samuna fa-huwa samin" (fat). Examples of what came on the weight of "fa'l": "sahula fa-huwa sahl" (easy), "sa'uba fa-huwa sa'b" (difficult). The poet's saying: (Zaydun Sahlun) is a Subject and Predicate. He said: (And 'Fa'il' for 'Fa'ila' with Kasra, perpetuate, like 'Af'al', 'Fa'lan' if it was intransitive) meaning: Every intransitive verb on the weight of "fa'ila" with a broken middle, its Active Participle comes on the weight of "fa'il" which is predominant like "fariha fa-huwa farih" (happy), "batira fa-huwa batir" (arrogant); or on the weight of "af'ala" if it indicates color like "khadira fa-huwa akhdar" (green), "hamira fa-huwa ahmar" (red), "sawida fa-huwa aswad" (black); or on the weight of "fa'lan" like "shabi'a fa-huwa shab'an" (full), "'atisha fa-huwa 'atshan" (thirsty), "sakira fa-huwa sakran" (drunk). Sometimes the three weights combine like "sha'itha fa-huwa sha'ith, and ash'ath, and sha'than" (disheveled). Thus some said: And perhaps they combined like sha'ith, and like sha'than, and like al-ash'ath.

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And 'Fa'il' for the open 'Fa'ala' and the … broken if it is transitive .....................

The Explanation: And the meaning of his saying: (And 'Fa'il' for 'Fa'ila' with Kasra, perpetuate) is: The Active Participle which is on the weight of "fa'il" is always brought for "fa'ila" with a broken middle. His saying: (adim) is an imperative from 'adama'. His saying: (if it was intransitive) meaning: on the condition that "fa'ila" with the broken middle is intransitive, not transitive. He said: (And 'Fa'il' for the open 'Fa'ala' and the broken if it is transitive) meaning: Every verb on the weight of "fa'ala" with an open middle - whether intransitive like "dhahaba" or transitive like "daraba", "kataba" -, or on the weight of "fa'ila" with a broken middle provided it is transitive like "hafiza", "fahima", then the Active Participle comes from them on the weight of "fa'il", such as: "dhahaba fa-huwa dhahib" (goer), "daraba fa-huwa darib" (hitter), "kataba fa-huwa katib" (writer), "hafiza fa-huwa hafiz" (preserver), "fahima fa-huwa fahim" (understander). And his saying: (if it is transitive) meaning: provided that "fa'ila" with the broken middle is transitive. But if it is intransitive, it was mentioned in the previous verse that its Active Participle is on the weight of "fa'il", or "af'al", or "fa'lan".

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
................... … .................. For other than this, it is transferred
The weight of its Mudari' with a Miem joined … at its beginning, and break what follows the last.

The Explanation: After the poet mentioned the form of the Active Participle from the triliteral verb, he mentioned that it comes from non-triliteral verbs, saying: (For other than this, it is transferred) meaning: For other than the triliteral. It means that the Active Participle comes from non-triliteral verbs on the weight of its Present tense (Mudari'), except that the Mudari' letter is replaced with a joined (Damma) Mim, and what is before its last letter is broken (Kasra), such as: "akrama yukrimu fa-huwa mukrim" (honorer), "intalaqa yantaliqu fa-huwa muntaliq" (departer), "istakhraja yastakhriju fa-huwa mustakhrij" (extractor). Thus the poet said: (The weight of its Mudari' with a Miem joined at its beginning, and break what follows the last). So his saying: (The weight of its Mudari') means: on the weight of the Present. His saying: (with a Miem joined) means: the Mudari' letter is replaced by a joined Miem. His saying: (at its beginning) means: the Miem is at its start. His saying: (and break what follows the last) means: and break the letter before the last one.

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And if you open it, then 'Maf'ul' you intend … and this weight from the Triliteral is consistent.

The Explanation: When the poet finished discussing the Active Participle, he began discussing the Passive Participle (Ism Maf'ul) from the triliteral verb and others. He started by discussing its formation from non-triliteral verbs, saying: (And if you open it, then 'Maf'ul' you intend) meaning: And if you want the Passive Participle from the verb exceeding three letters, then open (Fatha) the letter before the last of its Active Participle, such as: "mukram" (honored), "muntalaq" (departed from), "mustakhraj" (extracted), "mustanbat" (deduced) and so on. Then he mentioned the Passive Participle from the Triliteral, saying: (and this weight) meaning: the weight of "maf'ul" (from the Triliteral is consistent) meaning: it is the analogy for the Passive Participle from the Triliteral absolutely. So every triliteral verb, whether on the weight of "fa'ula" with joined middle, or "fa'ila" with broken middle, or "fa'ala" with open middle, the Passive Participle from it is brought on the weight of "maf'ul", such as: "mashrub" (drunk), "ma'kul" (eaten), "madrub" (hit), "masruq" (stolen), "maqtul" (killed).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
Chapter on Masdars (Verbal Nouns)
From 'Fa'ula' the joined, the measurement of the Masdar … is 'Fa'alah' [and] 'Fu'ulah', mention for it.

The Explanation: Chapter on Masdars. Masdars are of two types: Auditory (Sama'i - irregular) and Analogical (Qiyasi - regular). The Auditory ones are more numerous than the Analogical ones, but the poet did not discuss them; rather, he limited himself to the Analogical ones. He began by discussing the Masdar of "fa'ula" with the joined middle, saying: (From 'Fa'ula' the joined, the measurement of the Masdar is 'Fa'alah' [and] 'Fu'ulah', mention for it) meaning: Every verb on the weight of "fa'ula" with the joined middle, the analogy of its Masdar is to come on the weight of "fa'alah" or "fu'ulah", such as: "zarufa zarafah" (to be witty), "fasuha fasahah" (to be eloquent), "shaju'a shaja'ah" (to be brave), "sahula suhulah" (to be easy), "sa'uba su'ubah" (to be difficult). His saying: (qays) means: analogy, and (fa'alah and fu'ulah) in the poet's speech are the object of his saying: (udhkur) meaning: Mention for "fa'ula" 'fa'alah' and 'fu'ulah'.

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And 'Fa'ila' the broken, intransitive, 'Fa'al' … its analogy is 'Fa'l' for the falling [transitive] that occurred.
And 'Fa'ala' the opened, from it the Masdar … is 'Fa'l' ..................................

The Explanation: He said: (And 'Fa'ila' the broken, intransitive, 'Fa'al') meaning: Every intransitive verb on the weight of "fa'ila" with a broken middle, the analogy of its Masdar is to come on the weight of "fa'al", such as: "fariha farahan" (happiness), "batira bataran" (arrogance), "ghadiba ghadaban" (anger), "'atisha 'atashan" (thirst) and so on. His saying: (And 'Fa'ila' the broken) means: broken middle letter. (Intransitive) means: on the condition it is intransitive. As for the transitive, the analogy of its Masdar is to come on the weight of "fa'l" with a silent middle, thus the poet said: (its analogy is 'Fa'l' for the falling that occurred) such as: "fahima fahman" (understanding), "thalima thalman" (notching). His saying: "(for the falling)" means: for the transitive verb, because the transitive is called "the falling" (al-waqi') due to its action falling upon the object. He said: (And 'Fa'ala' the opened, from it the Masdar is 'Fa'l') meaning: And every verb on the weight of "fa'ala" with an open middle, if it is transitive, the analogy of its Masdar is to come on the weight of "fa'l" with a silent middle, such as: "daraba darban" (hitting), "fataha fathan" (opening), "bahatha bahthan" (searching), "ba'atha ba'than" (sending).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
........................ … ...... 'Fu'ul' in intransitive is mentioned.
And 'Fa'il' came like 'dabib', and 'Fu'al' … like 'surakh', 'Fa'alan' for transition.

The Explanation: But if it is intransitive, the analogy of its Masdar is to come on the weight of "fu'ul", such as: "qa'ada qu'udan" (sitting), "jalasa julusan" (sitting), "dakhala dukhulan" (entering), "khada'a khudu'an" (submitting). Thus the poet said: ('Fu'ul' in intransitive is mentioned). Except that it is frequently heard regarding "fa'ala" the intransitive with open middle that its Masdar comes on the weight of "fa'il" if it indicates movement/march, such as: "rahala rahilan" (departure); or on the weight of "fu'al" if it indicates sound, such as: "da'a du'a'an" (calling); or on the weight of "fa'alan" if it indicates motion and disturbance, such as: "dara dawaranan" (rotation). Thus the poet said: (And 'Fa'il' came like 'dabib', and 'Fu'al' like 'surakh', 'Fa'alan' for transition) meaning: The Masdar for intransitive "fa'ala" came on the weight of "fa'il", such as: "dabba dabiban" (crawling); and on the weight of "fu'al" like "sarakha surakhan" (screaming); and on the weight of "fa'alan" if "fa'ala" indicates transition and motion, such as: "fada fayadanan" (flooding), "jara jarayanan" (flowing), "ghala ghalayanan" (boiling). Also, it is heard that the Masdar from intransitive "fa'ala" comes on the weight of "fi'alah" if it indicates a craft or guardianship, such as: "kataba kitabah" (writing), "sana'a sina'ah" (manufacturing), "khata khiyatah" (sewing), "darasa dirasah" (studying), "waliya wilayah" (guardianship). It is also heard that the Masdar from intransitive "fa'ala" comes on the weight of "fu'al" if it indicates a disease, such as: "sa'ala su'alan" (coughing), "zukima zukaman" (cold/flu), "sada'a suda'an" (headache).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
And 'Fa'lah' for an instance like 'Khalsah' … ........................................

The Explanation: (And 'Fa'lah' for an instance like 'Khalsah') meaning: The Noun of Instance (Ism al-Marrah) from the triliteral verb absolutely, whether intransitive or transitive, is on the weight of "fa'lah", such as: "jalasa jalsah" (a sitting), "akala aklah" (an eating), "qa'ada qa'dah" (a sitting). His saying: (like 'Khalsah') is from ikhtilas: which is taking something quickly, and al-khalsah is a single instance of snatching. However, it is a condition in the foregoing that the Masdar is not originally built with a 'Ta'. If it is built with a 'Ta' like "rahmah" (mercy), "nafkhah" (blow), then it does not indicate the single instance [by form alone]. If an instance is intended from it, it is described by unity (the word 'one'), so it is said: "rahima rahmatan wahidatan" (he had mercy once), "nafakha nafkhatan wahidatan" (he blew once). As for forming the Instance from other than the triliteral verb, it is by adding a 'Ta' to its end, such as: "intalaqa intilaqah" (a departure), "istakhraja istikhrajah" (an extraction).

book_title: Fath al-Karim al-Latif in Explaining 'Bakurat al-Ta'rif bi-l-Muhimm min al-Tasrif' by Sheikh Muhammad Hammad bin Ahmed Al-Shanqiti
text:
......................... … And 'Fi'lah' for a manner like 'Khilsah'
